IlQxfTmJDtti8ep5KNj1AQ.text: Vegas never ceases to amaze. Wanting to get away from the unlimited food offerings, looked around for a noodle joint. In an unassuming strip joint (not the dirty kind), we walked into Mian Noodles. After asking for recommendations, we settled on the Zhajiang Mian and the special Chengdu cold noodles. We selected the radish appetizer and the marinated pork appetizer as well. Tip #1, check in, write a note get 1 of 4 free appetizer options. Tip #2 if you want the spare ribs with your noodles, don't get here when it opens. They cook it in the morning and takes about an hour to finish.   Onto the food. The radish appetizer was surprising! Slightly sweet, texturally rubbery and a little spicy. Sure doesn't sound appetizing when written in words, but don't knock it til you try it! Especially if it's free :) Next up was the marinated pork. We thought it was like meat meat, but I believe it was more like pork jowl. For those who've had it, it's either a love or hate; there is no inbetween.   The noodles themselves were super flavorful and chewy. The cold noodle was a sesame, peanut base slightly sweet and the zhajiang mien was savory with a soy sauce based sauce and minced pork and some baby bok Choy. Wash down the meal with complementary mung bean water and this makes for a fantastic low price meal for two!

ruNott6Naxg2mq1XEtyZHQ.text: Wow! Everything was delicious here, even the mung bean drink! The sweet and sour soup with crunchy beans and thin noodles, the short rib soup, the chaoshu bone soup as well as chili oil dumplings, and the pickled beef noodle soup were all amazing. The flavors here are complex, it's not just straight spice - the spice in each dish has a place in the recipe and is balanced out by other flavors. I also loved the steamed egg and mince pork appetizer - the broth was delicious!

2xOb4NGhs0nXTrGFaUV5tQ.text: Came on a thursday night. Got seated around 8:25pm and ordered at 8:30pm. We did not get our food until 9:05pm. I asked the waitress why it took so long and she said they only had one stove going and there were too many people in the restaurant... So strange.

vyMWElZoPkS6DdpCCt0FeA.text: Noodles are out of this world. I've lived in Chengdu and Chongqing and after coming back to the States, it's been hard to find authentic Sichuan food. These noodles are it!! I recommend the Chengdu Zajiang mian

Chili oil chaoshou 3. Chengdu zajiang noodle The cold mung bean beverage is key to cooling off your tongue.  Can't wait to try the SGV location in LA.

5AaDAINNSJcsBU5ifyB59g.text: Mian it's been a while since I wrote a review, big shout out to Ben the community manager for reeling me back in!  In the mian time since my last review, I had a blast at Mian! The chili oil wontons are absolutely spectacular, the noodles have just the right texture, and the broth's real good for a satisfying slurp fest.   They even have a cute paper table cover and very well decorated menus. I'm surprised by their attention to detail and the authenticity of their noodles. You can get'em real spicy with sichuan peppers or, if you don't want to be sweating your socks off, go for a refreshing clear broth zajiang noodles like I did (sweating in Las Vegas is killer lol). I'd definitely go here again and recommend you do the same ;) 5/5 food and design

Mtr-VPOXZLrOT4pyhh7PQQ.text: After a long day in Vegas, I was craving MIAN's Chengdu Zajiang Noodles. I was also super excited to order the steamed egg with minced pork, but unfortunately, that was not available at the time. When the noodles came out I was very excited. My first experience at MIAN in San Gabriel was great. I thought that the noodles were sooooooo good.   Unfortunately, the Las Vegas location was a bit let down. The noodles ended up being bland and very oily. I was able to try the Spicy Black Fungus and thought it was pretty good. They're pickled.   I will definitely make a trip to one in SoCal soon to make up for this experience.

YWm6_K1qDthJBvuT3oIb5A.text: Located in Chinatown, this restaurant is great for those who love spicy food and noodles. There are also items on the menu that are not spicy. Lightly sweetened mung bean soup is served instead of water when seated. (You can ask for water too). My mother used to make mung bean soup growing up so it was a very homey touch when I saw it. Upon ordering, the server will ask what level spice do you prefer if the item you're ordering is spicy.   Chili oil chaoshou, spare rib noodles (spice level: medium), and house beef noodles (spice level: medium). The house beef noodles soup was more spicy compared to the spare rib noodles when both spice level was medium. Both the beef and spare ribs were super tender and delicious. The chili oil chaoshou is basically a pork dumpling in hot chili oil which I find to be absolutely scrumptious!! The meat was juicy and flavorful while the chili oil compliments it very well.   Definitely give MIAN a try if you love everything noodles and spice!!

Service is quick & friendly. Food is fresh & delicious :)   I hope you decide to give them a try.

hLK1v1VJEpGGZjx5PXISMw.text: Enter MIAN Las Vegas edition.  After a long drive from Zion back to Los Angeles over the Labor Day weekend, we tried to stop at Kaya Sushi for some sushi. Unfortunately the wait was 30 minutes and we wanted to eat quickly so we could get back to activities on the Strip.  SPICY BLACK FUNGUS I ordered the Spicy Black fungus side, which has a light pickled flavor and it tasted pretty fresh and crisp. It came at a decent size and price. Got it for free for writing a Yelp review.  SICHUAN COLD NOODLES Their typical noodles served not quite icy cold, but cold enough. The sweet and spicy paste should be mixed so that the flavor is dispersed throughout the noodles. Like with the other dishes, the add-one are all extra priced except for the free 100g noodles. I tried the fried egg and intestines. The egg was a bit over cooked as the egg yolk had become chalky. The intestines on the other hand were nicely stewed which was a nice complement to the dish. The only thing I did not like was that on its own the noodles are kind of plain. At their price point, I feel like they should put a little more into it to make it more interesting.

FXhkIbXKNqvzfoTxrTZS9g.text: This review is looong overdue and I am more than convinced...MIAN is the spot for Szechuan cold noodles!!! The spicyness just keeps you wanting MORE!! The spicy, peanut Szechuan pepper sauce is sooo delicious and the noodles are always cooked just right!!  Warning though: the sauce includes a heaping scoop of fresh, ground garlic! Vampires be gone!!    I love that you can get extra noodles for FREE and their appetizers are tasty and a good size. The spicy radish and spicy black fungus are my faves!!  At $1.99, the portion is generous and those peppers in the spicy black fungus?! Whooo, they spice up any fungi!!! K, won't take up mushroom with puns...onto my review~  To help settle all the spice, you are given a Mian mug filled with a cold, slightly sweetened mung bean drink.  It is MAGIC!  It subdues the spicyness so you can continue enjoying the heat!! :P On my most recent visit, they didn't have it though.  Hoping they were just out for the day.  I have tried some of the soup dishes and other non-soup dishes, but the Szechuan cold noodle is where it's at!!

cd-m0_1DsBe50RXd59jSpw.text: We were craving something delicious and spicy after a few days on the strip. We're also big fans of Sichuan food, so we gave Mian a try. We got the spicy radish, the cold noodles, and the hot and sour noodles. Both noodle dishes were so flavorful and delicious. You can add additional items to your dishes such as meat, fried egg, etc.  The noodles were really the star of the dishes we tried. They were so fresh and chewy, and what's better is that you can get extra noodles for free (although we didn't because the portion size was already pretty filling). They also give a really tasty free appetizer - cabbage in Sichuan spices. This was probably better than the radish we ordered, so you may want to try it first before deciding to order an appetizer. The mung bean drink also goes well with the food and helps numb the spices a bit. Yum.  The flavor was so on point here. Spicy without being too overwhelming and just the right amount of mala. Wish we had this restaurant in the Bay area. Prices are also very, very reasonable. Service was fast. Skip the buffets and come here instead.

dWCoKjlU05Ajia6BKQiuRA.text: I've recently been craving Szechuan food quite a bit, even in the summer heat, and MIAN did a great job satisfying my taste buds.  I love the modern menu and cute placemat. I ordered the house beef noodle and shared the pork dumplings. The medium spice for the noodle was a pretty good level for this lover of spicy foods, but I may opt for the next level of spice in the future to truly get that mouth numbing sensation. I also enjoyed the noodles that were just the perfect texture.   Strangely, the pork dumplings were served when I had almost finished my noodles. Oh man, they were worth the wait though. The sauce they were dumped in (heehee), was slightly sweet and so delicious. There were 12 in an order.  I was stuffed after my meal. I'm glad there are locations in southern California close to where I live. I'd definitely go back!

8WHFYh18kBULYPA6OBdfxg.text: My buddy was in town and looking for something different. We'd already been to Yummy Box (great food) and weren't feeling like AYCE sushi so we thought we'd give Mian Sichuan Noodles a try. We went on a Tuesday evening around 8PM and the place wasn't too busy and we were seated immediately. The staff was pretty attentive. The interior was nice, clean, and quiet. Keep in mind this is a Tuesday evening so other days and weekends might be different. Here's what we ordered and what we thought: Spicy Radish - This was crunchy and spicy. Tasted picked and vinegary. It wasn't bad and very reminiscent of Korean kimchi Marinated Pork - This was actually pork snout which made the meat kind of crunchy and chewy at the same time. If you have an aversion to pig snout then don't order this. The overall flavor wasn't bad, seasoned to be slightly spicy/salty? Spare Rib Noodles - This was very good according to my friend. It was spicy, but overall he felt the quantity of meat was a bit skimpy. He also ordered a side of chicken gizzard which was chewy but very salty and spicy. Zajiang Noodles with Peas (minced pork in dry noodles with egg) - This overall wasn't bad. The spiciness wasn't that bad at first, but it started to build up and became quite spicy. Over easy fried egg was okay. Minced pork was flavorful. Peas were meh. Overall this dish was fine. Bone Soup ChaoShou (wonton soup) - This was not spicy. Clear broth was pretty light in the flavor department. Wontons were the same in that they weren't really flavorful or stand out. They could use some soy sauce or something else. Overall it felt like it was a filler item like fries to a burger. It's something else you order to go along with your main dish, but by itself it's not really anything. SPOILER ALERT - Everything we ordered and had was SPICY. Burn your taste buds spicy! I was wearing a cap when I first started, but by the end I had to remove it since I was sweating from the spiciness. Overall, I felt the food was A-okay hence the 3 stars (not terrible, just not for me). I can't really see myself going back since I wasn't really a fan of this kind of food especially when there are so many other options around on Spring Mountain. youtu.be/hPEiQW52Jko

sVU98PnY4s2NTswuHOOYFg.text: Mian is an authentic style Szechuan Noodle Restaurant located in China Town in a small strip mall next to the China Town Plaza. This isn't a fancy place but you come here for the food.  They have cute placemats on the tables with instructions on how to eat the food and also to Yelp about your experience.  I enjoyed that they start you off with cold cup of sweetened mung bean soup that you drink to relieve you from mouth numbing spicy heat from the food.  We started off with the spicy radishes. They came out almost instantly after we ordered them with a small dish of complimentary sweet and sour slightly spicy cabbage. I liked the radishes. They were really different to me and I never had anything like them before. They were sort of spicy and crunchy.....sort of light. They sort of got me excited to try Szechuan Noodles.  I tried the Szechuan Cold Noodles. The actual noodles were very good and were silky and chewy and long I thought they were perfect. My noodles were slightly spicy.....so I was disappointed because I was expecting them to be at least as spicy as the radishes but really was hoping for fiery mouth numbing noodles. The taste to me was also something new and different to me. It was slightly sour but also had a small amount of sweetness to it....I didn't dis-like it but it's not something I crave.....  My husband got the Za Jiang with Peas (pork noodles). He asked for as spicy as they make it. His dish did come out spicier than mine but it was the same heat as the radishes. I tasted a small amount of his and I liked the flavors better in his dish.  When I say spicy people hear mild..........

Xnftz7ZpkTGP8xTPW-lp1A.text: The restaurant was a bit hard to find using the GPS because we were automatically drawn to the adjacent Chinatown Plaza instead of this small strip mall.  To be honest, this was our plan B noodle stop on our visit to Vegas.  It saved the day after we ditched our first stop due to the long wait-list.  Oddly, the place had no line at all when we got here - around 12 noon on a Sunday.  "Mian" is the Mandarin word for noodle. A rather rare sighting because here in US we tend to see the Cantonese equivalent, "mein", a lot more often; e.g. lo mein, chow mein, etc). Anyway, needless to say, noodles are their specialty here and I love noodles!  After we were seated, we were automatically served with a pitcher of mung bean tea. I'm not sure if this is the West Coast thing -- I've never had mung bean tea in my life and yet this was the second place that served it during our short visit. It was nice and soothing.  OK on to the dishes:  Piquant Intestine Noodle Soup $8.99. This was the first time I had it. It's exotic for sure. The spicy broth went very well with the chewy intestines. It was good.  House Beef Noodle Soup $9.99. This was the best dish among what we ordered. Beef was extremely tender and the broth very tasty with a hint of sweetness.  Chengdu ZaJiang Noodle $8.99. Not recommended. The serving size was tiny. It should have been a small plate. The ground pork was of the run-of-the-mill soy sauce marinade variety.  For all three, the noodle itself was unimpressive. It didn't really stand out as particularly good.  Service was excellent; however, it hit a sour note when I was told that I would receive a free appetizer if I show them a 5 star review... I had to pass.

X3FD6W0iQgVMCDYXYynSmg.text: 5 stars for the authentic flavors and the amazing Zajiang mian which was perfectly al dente and had a very balanced sweet/spicy/savory profile. We ordered it at a medium spicy level and it was just right. Would definitely order this again the next time I come back.   4 stars for the house beef noodle soup. Noodles were also perfectly cooked and the beef chunks were plenty tender and flavorful. Only thing is the broth is more numbing spicy oil than beef soup, so if you're more into the Taiwanese style sweet and spicy beef noodle soup than the Szechuan numbing spice kind, this is a bit intense. Medium spicy was borderline too spicy for me, and I'm a high spice tolerance girl.   We also ordered the spicy black fungus and devoured it in less than 3 minutes. Delicious.   Service was great, got seated quickly and was immediately given a pitcher of cold mung bean drink. Perfect after coming in from 100 degree Las Vegas weather, and cuts the spice of the food surprisingly well! Would come back to try their other house recommendations and reorder that Zajiang mian!

meu4FbOy5heKUY-j8-elTA.text: Really great portions and flavors. I am a fan of noodle soup and growing up eating it, there's just things you look for. It seems as if Mian has the perfect noodles to go with a spicy broth. You can make some items mild but their normal spicy is definitely a hint spicier than I can take. Each bowl averages about $9.99. I came and ordered the house special beef noodle soup. Must try!  Also ordered the chili oil with their version of wontons. So delicious and picture worthy! What I love about this place is that their menu has a picture to go with each item. They also bring your food out super fast. Located in a popular shopping plaza, they have plenty of parking for this corner restaurant.

69ZziIfaXfdvstNWAQg9Qg.text: I walked in to great ambiance and delicious smell of authentic Chinese food. The place is well lit, clean, and has a very customer friendly menu -- easy to understand what the options are, which is spicy, and which is soupy. I'd like to stay unbiased for this review since I personally do not enjoy and cannot eat any spicy food, but from what I can see and smell off of the spicy dishes we ordered, they are legit. Just beware if you don't eat spicy food, your only noodle options will have no meat in them. Some non-spicy options I enjoyed are the minced pork steam egg and the non-spicy wonton. I'd come back again to take friends here -- especially ones who like the spicy Sichuan style.

gfwcMV8VMLMo871en8pM5g.text: I love Mian! I frequent the one in California, but had to stop at Mian on my Vegas trip. This location thankfully had no wait on a Tuesday night. Quick service, great food.  Update-- stopped once again on the way back home for lunch. Utah was fun but it was time for some noodles. It was so hot, I opted for the Szechuan Cold Noodle, little spicy, and it was AMAZING. How did I go so long without trying this noodle?? Seriously made my day. Service was still quick and great.

GfXqK-diG7KPYPAoa7y5Uw.text: I tried the Szechuan cold noodles, the Spare rib noodles and the Chili Oil Pork Dumplings. Parking is not the best because of the plaza. The interior feels authentic enough. I really like their dumplings because the meat is blended perfectly. The skin of the dumplings are perfect in shape and it doesn't stick. I really enjoyed the noodles as well, when you mix the noodles, sauce and onions it creates something simple yet flavorful. My friend didn't enjoy the spare ribs noodles as much but that because she couldn't eat spicy haha. (But I finished it for her, in my opinion the spare ribs were great) I would definitely come back because they have some great dumplings, the price point is fair and they have great customer service.

sTQvNxN4JZ0BC-wrmAwJUA.text: Delicious noodles here at Mian!!! I always get the hot and sour noodle soup. Perfectly savory and sour. I wish I had the stomach to order extra noodles, which is free. I think starting at a medium spice level is the way to go. Medium is not extremely spicy, but just enough to get your nose running a bit. The mushroom appetizer provides a little more crunch and acidity to your   It may be better to come in the afternoon. Although they open at 10:30, when I came in around 10:45 they did not have the mung bean soup available and were still prepping  appetizers. I was halfway done with my noodles by the time the fungus mushrooms came out.  Also, do not expect too great of service. It's a small restaurant, so it's easy to call your waiter over for requests and the check.

bc0goZcqRUAAwdZmryAPUQ.text: You can tell they take pride in much of what they do here. From the place mat to the menu to the complimentary mung bean soup in place of ice water. Service is quick and friendly, noodles are delicious. I'd come back next time I'm in town.

_MzryKz_l49XI2QaOR_ytQ.text: Very delicious noodle place. If you live the bold, spicy flavors that characterize Sichuan cuisine, then you will love Mian.   Their soup broth very flavorful. I only tried the Hauxing Fried Egg Noodle, but it had a great tomatoey flavor to it. But what really blew me away about this place was their Chili Oil Chaoshou. The Chili Oil had such a deep and complex flavor. It was salty, sweet, spicy, savory... But none of the individual flavors were too overpowering.   There's this cool modern style that resonates throughout the restaurant from their menus to the good presentation. I can't wait to return.

OPZjzZDUUI8l_cWCPZe3Ow.text: Must try! Their mung bean water is something to look forward too when coming here. Definitely recommend if you love spicy flavorful chinese noodles!

4twrxs7L6zl1o18HwPMSGA.text: Definitely more than just another noodle house. This place has a clean environment, professional and courteous staff, and amazing dishes! The Beef noodles were fantastic, as well as the Gizzard noodles, and Ziajang noodles. The pork dumplings were better than any others I have had. A great spot we will come back! The Chiangdou province was well represented. Oh, and the mung bean "soup" (really more like a sweet iced tea) was wonderful, as was the plum juice.

zKLgtqPwsnJibUsE71MLQg.text: My wife and I ordered the house beef noodle and beef pickled noodle to share with each other.  Our waiter was quick to point out that their dishes was on the  spicier side.  I went with a lighter spice level on the house beef noodle, which ended up perfect for me.  The dark beef broth was saltier and less sweet than some of other beef noodle soups that I've had.  Very flavorful.  The beef pickled noodle had a distinctively different broth.  Light in color, but heavily seasoned with numbing spice (peppercorn), which the waiter did warn us about.   And he wasn't kidding! Both my wife and I couldn't feel our mouths after a few bites.  The broth flavor was good, but we probably would've enjoyed it more if it had less peppercorn.  Overall the food was good and we appreciate our waiter for being upfront about the food.  Would definitely come back again.

2hr2QFCSyWNEt2hxzYgpOw.text: This is very cool. I don't think I've ever had real authentic Chinese cuisine. The Sichuan noodles are amazing, as well as the mung bean soup. The flavors are bold and delicious. Nothing left wanting.

gmC9IHfLCeenndyi-j3-wA.text: The service is terrible. I was there once before and the intestine noodle soup was good except that the veggies and intestine was noticeably less than what they used to give out (based on the posted pictures from customers on yelp reviews) or it was just that one time unlucky for me, the chef did not give me much but since I was craving for it so I still drove all the way to the restaurant to get my favorite noodle soup. I was there at around 11:25am on Saturday. They were a little busy and a few people were waiting to be seated. So I decided to order for take out instead of waiting. When I asked the waitress for takeout orders, she was so rude: "these people sitting here still did not place their orders yet so you need to wait 30 minutes." So I was like, wow....I have never had to wait 30 minutes to place a takeout order. I can understand waiting for a table. That's just ridiculous!!! Then, of course I just left disappointed and dissatisfied. That's the worst customer service I have ever experienced in a restaurant.

I-iV9q-9J_JyetyuQHynkg.text: Location and ambiance 2/5 Staff 4/5 Food 3/5 Likeliness to return 2/5 Likeliness to recommend 1/5  Location and ambiance: Located in a busy plaza on Sp.Mt. that typically already have huge issues with parking. - the restaurant is very half assed and unfinished.  I understand they removed all the booths/ decor from the previous tenant. But they didn't bother covering up any holes or patch up the walls with new paint. There's several hanging lights missing. Personally to me.. if a restaurant is new, I expect it to look like the previous tenant cuz it's reusable or something new and turn key.  I don't wanna dine in a place that looks like someone just moved out.  Staff: Staff is friendly and nice.  We were greeted promptly and water and comp appetizers arrived right away after we sat down.  My only complaint is the staff is constantly on their cell phone. They are super nice and polite when you get their attention but they're not very attentive on their own.  Food: We ordered the steamed egg with minced meat.  Came out super fast.  A little too salty for me but my husband thought it was good.   Then he ordered the first thing on the menu, pig intestines noodle.  All we tasted was the heavy peppercorn and no other depth of flavor coming through.  My husband had to ask for soysauce and vinegar to tweak it.  I ordered the Hot and Sour Noodle which was tasty and I loved the thin homemade noodle texture. Doesn't blow my mind, but it was a good choice.  Likeliness to return: For what it is, we're probably not going to return.  So far there isn't a flavor that I crave.  However, it's not terrible so should any friends wanna dine here we wouldn't refuse.  Likeliness to Recommend: Less likely.

kD0VM6Vba6msyg_Gxbx_mA.text: This is the best Chongqing street noodle (xiao mian) we have ever had in US. My boyfriend is from Chongqing, and of course he has a ridiculously high standard when judging Chongqing noodles, and this time here in Vegas, he gave this place a five star. We ordered the traditional zajiang noodles with peas, and the piquant intestine noodles. Both are tasty and very authentic. The noodles are the specially made using alkali water, which is considered as the most important component in the Chongqing noodles. Every dish here indicates the noodles and dishes are cooked by an exceptionally good and experienced chef from Chongqing. We are from New York, so if possible, we highly recommend them to open a branch in Manhattan, or Flushing, it will be the best Chongqing noodles in New York with absolutely no doubts. It will be a home-like place for people from Chongqing.

NK088ml_4EnQooODb4v63g.text: this has been my craving ever since I first tried this place out. it's currently my favorite place at the moment which is surprising because I'm a little b---h when it comes to spicy things.   the staff is a little bit awkward, but are attentive and very helpful. the place itself is small and clean. the drawings and messages past customers write are very cute and unique.   food: so my boyfriend hates the numbing spice. I don't mind spicy but my stomach minds it. a lot. so every time we order, he requests no numbing spice and I request less spicy. both of us are content with our foods every single time! my favorite item is the house beef noodle less spicy and it's the perfect amount of spice for me every time.   also, I could live off of that mung bean soup. I'm not kidding. it pairs with their noodles so well. I just can't.   the only thing we were slightly disappointed in was the steamed egg because it had little to no flavor. the texture was amazing, but it was pretty "eh" to us. but that's ok, I just want noodles and soup and we good.

However at the end I realized I was still quite hungry, so really you're not getting enough bang for your buck. Yes you can order more noodles but by then you're out of meat and veggies to go with it.  The wontons are average but they charge an arm and a leg for them.

qWiNLYxCvoSvu0CDR3VOew.text: Our family stopped in here one day for lunch.  Mom was feeling noodles and we'd just had ramen the day before so this was a different sort.  The name of the game is Szechuan, spicy noodles.  They don't have many other dishes other than a few appetizers so get your mind focused on noodles!  The four of us all ordered different things. I liked my mom's the best - the intestine noodles.  The intestines were very tender and nicely seasoned.    Brother ordered the hot and sour wontons which I felt were really good.  He thought the regular spicy wontons were better (less soupy).    Hubby's minced pork noodles went so fast so I guessed he liked it?  Finally, my noodles.  I wasn't in the mood for spicy so I got their bone broth noodles.  This did not come with any meat so I added some beef.  I wasn't a huge fan of this.  The soup was ok...but not really great paired with noodles. The broth was already sort of on the light side.  Paired with noodles, it just washed out the whole dish. Also the side of beef was super hard and not nearly cooked down enough.    For the sides, we really liked the cloud mushroom dish.  We ended up ordering two of them.  Service was nice.  They were very generous with their offer of green bean soup refills (nice and refreshing to go with the spicy foods).  If you're in the mood for spicy noodles, definitely come have a bowl here!

0dodWxapS8eYb1ie18cCzg.text: I think Mian is great! The restaurant isn't that big and it's in one of the shopping plazas with inadequate parking spots, but the food is tasty and affordable.  The menu isn't big, but offers several noodle dishes (mian means noodle), almost all of which are less than $10. You also get served complimentary pickled cabbage and complimentary refillable green bean soup (I LOVE green bean soup). To top it off, they also provide FREE unlimited noodle refills.  The noodle dishes are all very authentic and tasty. The noodles themselves are fresh and chewy as well. Service is decent. Decor is quaint, especially with all of the comment cards hung up.  All in all, between the taste, freebies, and value for price, I highly recommend Mian for a quick and inexpensive yet delicious meal.

TwAIwPwMdonzi9DZbcRQhw.text: Appetizers:  - sliced spicy beef: it was alright. It was indeed spicy but it was too dry for me - Steamed egg with minced pork: this was my favorite one! Egg was smooth and the minced pork had a nice subtle sweet flavor to it.  - spicy back fungus: this one was alright also. It was spicy but they also put too much vinegar in it and that overpowered the spiciness.   Noodles: - Spare rib soup and Spicy house beef soup: both soup had the same broth (at least they tasted the same to me).  The soup itself was okay. It had a layer of chili oil on the top which is expected in Szechuan cooking. I wasn't a big fan of the meat in each dish. Both the spare ribs and chunks of beef felt rough.  Overall, I most likely won't come back. It wasn't enough to wow me and plus, it's kinda far.

ZmvvZpBmAnQa0PruafYIEQ.text: Came here right before they closed for a couple of hours before the dinner shift, so it was pretty empty. The food here is ok. Sichuan dishes are an acquired taste. Service was fine since there was hardly anyone there. The prices were also decent. They started us out with a mung bean tea drink when we sat down. It's pretty tasty with a small hint of sweetness, but it does not look appetizing at all. We ordered the spare ribs noodle and the pickled beef noodle, both with an egg.  Spare rib noodle: i love spicy food, but it's kind of overpowering. Kind of like if you dumped a whole jar of chili oil in it, its not spicy but the flavor is too much. The noodles and bok choy were cooked fine. The noodles are similar to ramen noodles. The spare ribs tasted different, almost a gaminess kind of flavor. Not the flavors I was expecting.  Pickled beef noodle: this is a weird dish. It's kind of like a strong rosemary flavor, but the aftertaste numbs your mouth and is not a good feeling. The noodles were cooked fine, but I could not get past that rosemary numbness.   I probably wouldn't come back here again. It's different than the typical Asian noodles such pho, ramen, or udon. You have to have a certain palate for these kinds flavors to enjoy it.

To begin with I came alone and waited 10 minutes to be seated and I was the only one waiting.. then there was a dirty table that he finally cleaned and sat me there. The stench of whatever cleaning product he used was overbearing. Then when I asked for help with the menu and ask him how big the pork dumplings were, he said "2". I repeated back 2? h2ovjDDNXVE9FHConXsQNg.text: Haven't been so satisfied from noodles for such a long time.   Prices: prices are pretty decent over here, almost everything around $10. The appetizers are pretty affordable like $2 each.  Service: As soon as I walked in, the waitress greeted me and guided me to the seats. Instead of serving water, they serve green beans soup, it's free and refillable! They refill my cup for at least three times, very nice service.  Environment: the tables and chairs are made of wood, lots of customers notes hanging on the wall. It's a chill and casual dining place.  Food: I love the noodle that I ordered, which was special gizzard noodles, the gizzard doesn't gave me lots of surprises, but the noodle was bomb. The seasoning and the sauces were awesome. I only had little bit left over after I'm done eating, and I'm still taking it home.  Overall: No doubt that this place would be my first choice if I'm craving for Chinese noodle. Fair price and nice service.

7qG90LXXcMi5ETZDowAPUw.text: Warning: Szechuan spiciness is very different from the normal spiciness that we see in other cuisines. The heat coats your tongue, giving you that numbing feeling and heats you up from the inside over time. It's different from other spiciness where you feel the kick right away, even burning your lips if you get the sauce on it; therefore, be mentally prepared if this is your first time experiencing Szechuan cuisine.  With that being said, this place captures that burning flavor so well. They let you choose your spiciness level in each dish, I'd recommend starting out with 'mild' if this is your first time.  I ordered the house-beef noodle and I was not disappointed. The noodles were amazing and the broth that accompanied it was delicious, best I've had so far in Las Vegas.  In addition to the delicious spicy meal, the restaurant offers you a mug of mung-bean soup, which you consume like a tea, which helps to cool down your body temperature after your meal.   It's great that the customers are offered these drinks; however, it's also where this restaurant loses a star from my rating. The mung-bean soup that we're given were very little in quantity, it did not even fill up past half-way in the mug. Often in restaurants that I go to, the drink cups are fully filled, or comes within a big container for the customer to fill themselves. With the mung-bean soup being such a vital part to the meal, I'd expect the restaurant to give its customers a fully-filled mug.  Overall this restaurant is a great place to stop by to experience the burning essence of Szechuan flavor, perfect for cold days in Las Vegas.

I could not stop eating them - spicy, creamy, and so flavorful - the only thing I wish was different was for the egg to not be so done. It was hard to cut with my chopsticks and didn't integrate well in the dish. A creamy egg would have been much better IMO. ZiiUwPiVz766mSq7at3aVw.text: Craving fulfilled! I really wanted "spicy noodles" whatever that means. I was going to settle for some spicy instant ramen after a long day of work, but here comes Yelp to the rescue.  I ordered to-go and I went with the spicy cold noodle and the pork dumplings in chili oil. It was ready in about ten minutes and did not break the bank either.   I loved everything I ordered. Such good flavor! The noodle dish had good heat, but wasn't overly spicy. My lips and tongue were tingling though!  The noodles were a good texture. Lots of garlic. Total flavorbomb! It's vegan too!  The pork dumplings in chili oil were one of the better versions I've had. I liked that they packaged the dumplings separately from the sauce. Lemme tell you, that sauce is crack! It has a hint of sweetness which makes it oh so tasty!   I like how the menu is organized and you know which dishes are: soup, no soup, vegan, spicy, not spicy. kkonjuhVn3ToK74S_L8azw.text: This was my first time trying authentic Sichuan Noodles so I don't have much of a reference point but I know I liked what I had and so did everyone else in my party.   In Vegas kind of late and getting hungry, started Yelping for a noodle house. Typical Ramen shops popped up but this one caught my eye primarily because the photos and description looked very authentic when compared to the You Tube videos by The Food Ranger Trevor James eating his way around China. I was a little skeptical not realizing that Las Vegas has an area that has become a booming Asia Town in terms of shops and eateries.   We arrived at 8:45 pm and the place was empty but started filling up as we sat. Being unsure of much on the menu, we had a conversation with our server about what taste profiles we liked, what we were looking for and what some of her favorites were. She gave great advice along with a small free starter of pickled cabbage and some cold mung bean sweet soup that really was more of a refreshing beverage that cuts the heat more than anything.   As the food arrived, I was amazed by the new flavor profiles, especially the mouth-numbing quality of the Sichuan peppercorns and I loved how you can specify the spice level of your dish. If you want it hotter, just let them know. I thought about a piquant intestine noodle dish but opted for the spare rib noodle dish which was fantastic. Sampled everyone else's too and nobody got a bad meal.   The food was great and the setting/menu/taste is unique enough that it stimulates a lot of social conversation at the table unless, I suppose, you are dining with people that are experts on this regional cuisine. The food really was unique but I can easily see how it is a comfort food of Northern China. In the end, we spent about $40 for a party of 3 and had more food than we could possibly eat but it was a great experience and definitely a recommended non-ramen noodle place for the area.

There are plenty of great restaurants in the area though, so I doubt I'd come here again since the soup was just so awful.

iBxbG1FQiZXPq47RFQO4mg.text: Re: food, refer to the other 200 reviews. I'm in agreement. I come here often and will continue to do so.  When you come here, though, be aware that your favorite items may not be available. It is a truly terrible feeling to have your cravings denied, akin to the deep pangs of regret felt when you're lactose intolerant and the belly rumbles violently after one too many scoops of ice cream.   Allow me to spell it out for you. Of my approximately 20 trips (yes, I really love this place):  -4x they have not had the spare rib noodles in stock. Twice before noon. -3x they have "run out" of mung bean soup. Twice before noon. -1x I was given the last pour of mung bean soup, and the next customers that entered were handed a pitcher of water. -2x they did not have house beef noodles. -1x they did not have the steamed eggs available. Eggs. Eggs! Eggs!! Eggs!!! Eggs!!!! Eggs!!!!! -1x upon ordering the marinated pork, I was given a half portion without explanation. I didn't confirm, but I suspect it was due to low stock. -On the bright side, they always have the wood ear fungus, which is delicious.  These are all regular menu items, the mung bean soup in particular, which is delivered to every customer and heavily featured in their promotional materials as a differentiating factor. How are you not able to keep that on-hand to serve?  Who's in charge of this second-rate operation? Where's management? Is it a supply chain issue? Do they need to hire somebody to be responsible for inventory/ordering?  Is there a customer who sporadically and unpredictably comes in and places 137 orders to-go at 9 o'clock of the exact same items I like to order, thus depleting their stock?  Mian: One of life's great mysteries. Like the age of the universe. Or Fermi bubbles. Or how Daenerys traversed half the known world in one hour.* Elon Musk, you have some catching up to do.  *Spoiler? Oops.

iyrCEL08-uskW29Nmxb5yw.text: I came here from the Bay Area and this place is way better than Chong Qing Xiao Mian. I recommend the spare rib noodles and chili and oil Chaoshow dumplings.

photos.caption: Photo of MIAN | 滋味小面 - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Too good I forgot to take a picture lol

KEnmDdv72KnfDcNQfZd5BQ.text: I can't get over how good this place is.   First off they have the greatest dumplings in the world: The Pork Dumplings. These dumplings are soaking in this incredible soup, that I can't really explain to you. All I know is that it's a combination of sweet, salty, spicy, and savory. I would drink it if I could.   Next, the Huaxing Fried Egg Noodles. You have these perfectly cooked noodles sitting in a rich, savory, but also lightly sour broth. And the tomato they add, gives it a slight sourness that cuts through the savoriness of it.   This is one of the best restaurants in Las Vegas.

2JTwBfUw4lym3jXVTJg4_A.text: I stopped in here for a quick bite and what an incredibly pleasant surprise this tiny gem is. I tried the house beef noodles extra spicy. Insanely delicious. The broth was deep, flavorful and complex. The heat was powerful yet addictive. The sensation on my tongue was more tingly than burning. Sheer delicious delight. The beef was abundant and melt in your mouth braised to perfection. The noodles were excellent and flavorful. I also thoroughly enjoyed the complimentary mung bean soup and pickled cabbage. I can't wait to be back to dry different dishes and broths.

P2m9KEn07IeiuxT3no9r6Q.text: This is my first time coming... absolutely delicious beef noodle soup. The stock taste pretty unique and had just the right amount of spice as well as the meat being really tender. Very tasty definitely worth coming to.

pZ2lORCD068gmfbABcLBbA.text: Wow! Haven't had amazing beef noodles like this in a LONG time. The noodles were perfect (not soggy). I prefer my noodles to have a little bounce to them. The beef soup had exceed all expectations. The soup was flavorful and the beef was tender. My mom ordered the Ma-Lat noodles.. and boy does this dish live up to its name. First sips had my entire lips numb and tingly. Apparently the Szechuan pepper do that to you. The soup base on both dish was on point. Can't wait to come back!  We also ordered 2 appetizers. The radish was just okay for me, although my mom loved them. Some of the radish were too hard to chew. The fungus, on the other hand, was the best fungus dish I've ever had in my entire life. I'm a huge fan of vinegar - and this dish had the perfect combination of sour and sweet similar to pickled fungus.   For desert, we ordered 2 of the sweet jelly. This was definitely not something I've ever had before. If you like nuts - I definitely recommend this. Otherwise, if you're not a peanut lover like me, don't order this.   Ohhhh and how can I forget the kung bean soup!?? This restaurant serves kung bean soup for your drink! No need to order water -- as this soup will help cool your mouth from the burning sensation from the spicy noodles! The mung bean soup has a hint of sweetness to it, and the fact that mung beans are good for you - make this place a top contender for me for favorite noodle restaurant in Las Vegas!   The restaurant is small but very comfortable. No wait for a Sunday afternoon.

p9IQWlbecdq7FjBkEOzFLg.text: New noodle shop located where Yagyu Ramen used to be. They have another location in San Gabriel, California.   FOOD: Menu is not very ingredient specific. It only tells you 3 out of the 6 ingredients so beware if you're vegetating. Presentation is also poor, mine looked as if it had already been stirred for me.   Hauxing Fried Egg Noodles was served with thin noodles which I enjoyed and seemed to be vegetarian but because it was not marked I'll assume the broth was a meat broth. It was tasty and had almost a tomato soup style broth with a fried egg on top, tomato chunks and green onion. I don't know that I would this one again as I prefer clear broths but it was definitely tasty!   Chili Oil Chaoshou is a none soup dish. Just steamed dumpling sitting in a yummy bath of spicy chili oil was fantastic, although I wish the menu said what type of meat it was because I have no idea what I ate now. Otherwise the tastes were fantastic and was not over steamed.   ATMOSPHERE: Very plain inside, there is nothing on the bare white walls. There is one little tv in the wall turned off that looks to be the same one as the previous tenant. The only other decorations are two of their soup cups by the restaurant entry. It also looks as if there is the same brown wood furniture as the previous tenant.   STAFF AND SERVICE: Very friendly staff however not a very good flow of who handles customers walking in and those dining. We were approached by someone from the register and given menus while we stood at the door along with 4 other people waiting to dine. Upon entry there is a clip board with lines on it hanging so you can write in your party name and how many dining. Once seated they brought soup and water out immediately after being seated and the food came out very quickly which was great for the lunch hour. I definitely could have waited an additional minute if it made the appearance of my dish better though. There's no fun instagraming it as their place mat suggests if it's a messy bowl of food.   Overall I'll go again should someone mention we dine there.

7HJIdHn-g_84Ze_2W-5O5A.text: I've been holding off on this review for a while, but I've eaten here enough times now to say that this is most likely the best noodle spot in Las Vegas. The location it's in was once my favorite ramen restaurant in the valley, and this location remains a crown jewel in Chinatown with its signature spicy noodles.  To begin with, the food is incredible and has a nice kick to it. The best dish in my opinion is the Chengdu Zhajiang Noodles (with or without peas). Every bite is bursting with flavor and spicy goodness, and after you've eaten enough you get a nice tingly feeling in your mouth, thanks to the Sichuan pepper. And to cool down, you're given this sweet and delicious mung bean soup (free of charge!), which is a bit of an addiction for me.   The food is spicy, but not too spicy; the flavor remains prominent regardless of what part of the dish you're eating. The noodles are a perfect texture, not tough but not at all mushy. And the meat and veggies are cooked to perfection.  This may be hyperbole to some, but I believe this to be the perfect noodle bowl. It has reached the perfect, noodly equilibrium I seek out in a dish such as this.  Now I want you to understand that their regular spice level may be too spicy to some. I have had friends and family tell me, "I'm gonna have to order mild next time." But I think that's the best thing about this place. It IS spicy. There are so many "spicy" restaurants out there that don't give me a semblance of a kick. This isn't one of them. People who are spice enthusiasts and those with more sensitive tastes can find something to love at this restaurant.  There isn't much to say about the staff except that they stay on top of their game and are super friendly. They've always tended to my needs accordingly.  Anyhow, rather than continuing to ramble, I'll leave it at this: Try this place, you will most definitely want to come back and I promise that you will not regret it.

It was not too spicy or salty. My only complaint was amount of beef, but what was in there was very tender. My father got the pork and I tasted his and thought it was very good too. l2fBjAtcmaO7olt30FA0sg.text: Great value, tasty food.  We came in a large group so sampled almost the entire menu.  Highlights from "app" section are fungus (wood ear mushroom) fresh chili and vinegar. Radish fermented like an ultra crunchy kimchi.  Egg custard with beef (similar to a chawanmushi) All the dumplings are good, I like the pork in chili oil varietals but the savory broth versions are great as well, portions are very large.  Entree highlights were cold Szechuan noodle, bone broth soup with noodle and pickled beef noodle.  If it was more expensive it would be three stars as in the large scheme of Szechuan flavors it was mild and one dimensional. But value for the cost is good and the service team was kind and attentive. (Also msg usage was mild).

beSEs6p1jRdCYrBiyFLNow.text: OMG, this place is wonderful. I loved everything we tried from the spicy radishes, pickled cabbage, beef noodle soup, mung bean soup and iced jelly desert.  My partner had a tomato based noodle soup with a fried egg and sliced fresh tomatoes in it. He said it was excellent. I thought the service was outstanding. They offer various levels of spiciness which was a good thing. I think medium is hot enough for most people.  This is my first experience eating authentic Sichuan dishes.  We will be back.  I highly recommend Mian.

Ct0tHwGlfajlUiZyOoQBZQ.text: We came to Las Vegas and stuck here due to Hurricane Harvey. We are all tired of American food and craving for some authentic Chinese food. We accidentally arrived this place and decided to give it a try. This is a small restaurant but is very clean. The staff here are very friendly. They have cool mung bean soup in this hot summer day for free and refill instead of ice water. They also brought in Sichuan pickles as our appetizer. The pickle was authentic, not like Cantonese styled. Their Manu is short but every single dishes are tasty just as it is supposed to be. We ordered spicy sour wonton, house special rib noodle and Chengdu minced meat noodle. All tasted fabulous!  We definitely will come back. It beats any buffet on the stop after several days away from home.
